entry.title: Combined summary - Reconsidering block version number use
entry.summary: In July 2012, there was an email exchange among Gavin Andresen, Luke-Jr, Jeff, Peter, and Mike regarding ways to increase scalability in Bitcoin mining pools. Andresen proposed increasing the coinbase transaction version number to 2 instead of the block version, but this would require computing the percentage of the last 1,000 blocks that support the new version during the rollout. Luke-Jr suggested using the block version as an extra nonce to accommodate the increasing number of ASIC miners running at 1 TH/s per rig.Jeff noticed an issue with block 190192 having version==2 without a valid block height in the coinbase, but since it was in a part of the chain with zero other version==2 blocks, the height-in-the-coinbase rule would not be enforced. Peter suggested having more nonce space with fewer merkle calculations to ease the pool server work and reduce the number of unique transaction/coinbase sets to hold on to for checking old work when a solution is returned. However, Mike questioned the necessity of more nonce bits and asked if it was working around a performance bottleneck somewhere else.In response, Peter provided details on the amount of nonce required and changes for version 2 blocks, which would have "has height in the coinbase, and has a 1-byte version number with a 3-byte extranonce." The email also included contact information for Peter Vessenes, CEO of CoinLab. In conclusion, the email exchange discussed various proposals to increase scalability in Bitcoin mining pools and highlighted potential issues and consequences of each proposal.
